items.title: 3 things Will Douglas Heaven is into right now
items.summary: The most amazing drummer on the internet My daughter introduced me to El Estepario Siberianoโs YouTube channel a few months back, and I have been obsessed ever since. The Spanish drummer (real name: Jorge Garrido) posts videos of himself playing supercharged cover versions of popular tracks, hittinโฆ
items.body: The most amazing drummer on the internet My daughter introduced me to El Estepario Siberianoโs YouTube channel a few months back, and I have been obsessed ever since. The Spanish drummer (real name: Jorge Garrido) posts videos of himself playing supercharged cover versions of popular tracks, hitting his drums with such jaw-dropping speed and technique that he makes other pro drummers shake their heads in disbelief. The dozens of reaction videos posted by other musicians are a joy in themselves.  EL ESTEPARIO SIBERIANO VIA YOUTUBE Garrido is up-front about the countless hours that it took to get this good. He says he sat behind his kit almost all day, every day for years. At a time when machines appear to do it all, thereโs a kind of defiance in that level of human effort. Itโs why my favorites are Garridoโs covers of electronic music, where he out-drums the drum machine. Check out his version of Skrillex and Missy Elliotโs โRa Ta Ta โ and tell me it doesnโt put happiness in your heart. Finding signs of life in the uncanny valley Watching Sora ยญvideos of Michael Jackson stealing a box of chicken nuggets or Sam Altman biting into the pink meat of a flame-grilled Pikachu has givโฆ

items.title: Job titles of the future: Head-transplant surgeon
items.summary: The Italian neurosurgeon Sergio Canavero has been preparing for a surgery that might never happen. His idea? Swap a sick personโs headโor perhaps just the brainโonto a younger, healthier body. Canavero caused a stir in 2017 when he announced that a team he advised in China had exchanged heads betweโฆ
items.body: The Italian neurosurgeon Sergio Canavero has been preparing for a surgery that might never happen. His idea? Swap a sick personโs headโor perhaps just the brainโonto a younger, healthier body. Canavero caused a stir in 2017 when he announced that a team he advised in China had exchanged heads between two corpses. But he never convinced skeptics that his technique could succeedโor to believe his claim that a procedure on a live person was imminent. The Chicago Tribune labeled him the โP.T. Barnum of transplantation.โ Canavero withdrew from the spotlight. But the idea of head transplants isnโt going away. Instead, he says, the concept has recently been getting a fresh look from life-extension enthusiasts and stealth Silicon Valley startups. Career path Itโs been rocky. After he began publishing his surgical ideas a decade ago, Canavero says, he got his โpink slipโ from the Molinette Hospital in Turin, where heโd spent 22 years on staff. โIโm an out-of-the-establishment guy. So that has made things harder, I have to say,โ he says. Why he persists No other solution to aging is on the horizon. โItโs become absolutely clear over the past years that the idea of some incredible tech to reโฆ

items.title: Why inventing new emotions feels so good
items.summary: Have you ever felt โvelvetmistโ? Itโs a โcomplex and subtle emotion that elicits feelings of comfort, serenity, and a gentle sense of floating.โ Itโs peaceful, but more ephemeral and intangible than contentment. It might be evoked by the sight of a sunset or a moody, low-key album. If you havenโt eโฆ
items.body: Have you ever felt โvelvetmistโ?  Itโs a โcomplex and subtle emotion that elicits feelings of comfort, serenity, and a gentle sense of floating.โ Itโs peaceful, but more ephemeral and intangible than contentment. It might be evoked by the sight of a sunset or a moody, low-key album.   If you havenโt ever felt this sensationโor even heard of itโthatโs not surprising. A Reddit user named noahjeadie generated it with ChatGPT, along with advice on how to evoke the feeling. With the right essential oils and soundtrack, apparently, you too can feel like โa soft fuzzy draping ghost floating through a lavender suburb.โ Donโt scoff: Researchers say more and more terms for these โneo-ยญemotionsโ are showing up online, describing new dimensions and aspects of feeling. Velvetmist was a key example in a journal article about the phenomenon published in July 2025. But most neo-emotions arenโt the inventions of emo artificial intelligences. Humans come up with them, and theyโre part of a big change in the way researchers are thinking about feelings, one that emphasizes how people continuously spin out new ones in response to a changing world.  Velvetmist mightโve been a chatbot oneโฆ

items.title: MIT Technology Reviewโs most popular stories of 2025
items.summary: Itโs been a busy and productive year here at MIT Technology Review. We published magazine issues on power, creativity, innovation, bodies, relationships, and security. We hosted 14 exclusive virtual conversations with our editors and outside experts in our subscriber-only series, Roundtables, and hโฆ
items.body: It’s been a busy and productive year here at MIT Technology Review . We published magazine issues on power , creativity , innovation , bodies , relationships , and security . We hosted 14 exclusive virtual conversations with our editors and outside experts in our subscriber-only series, Roundtables , and held two events on MITโs campus. And we published hundreds of articles online, following new developments in computing, climate tech, robotics, and more. As the year winds down, we wanted to give you a chance to revisit a bit of this work with us. Whether we were covering the red-hot rise of artificial intelligence or the future of biotech, these are some of the stories that resonated the most with our readers.  We did the math on AIโs energy footprint. Hereโs the story you havenโt heard. Understanding AIโs energy use was a huge global conversation in 2025 as hundreds of millions of people began using generative AI tools on a regular basis. Senior reporters James OโDonnell and Casey Crownhart dug into the numbers and published an unprecedented look at AIโs resource demand, down to the level of a single query, to help us know how much energy and water AI may require moviโฆ

items.title: The paints, coatings, and chemicals making the world a cooler place
items.summary: Itโs getting harder to beat the heat. During the summer of 2025, heat waves knocked out power grids in North America, Europe, and the Middle East. Global warming means more people need air-ยญconditioning, which requires more power and strains grids. But a millennia-old idea (plus 21st-century tech) โฆ
items.body: Itโs getting harder to beat the heat. During the summer of 2025, heat waves knocked out power grids in North America , Europe , and the Middle East . Global warming means more people need air-ยญconditioning, which requires more power and strains grids. But a millennia-old idea (plus 21st-century tech) might offer an answer: radiative cooling. Paints, coatings, and textiles can scatter sunlight and dissipate heatโno additional energy required. โRadiative cooling is universalโit exists everywhere in our daily life,โ says Qiaoqiang Gan, a professor of materials science and applied physics at King Abdullah University of Science and Technology in Saudi Arabia. Pretty much any object will absorb heat from the sun during the day and radiate some of it back at night. Itโs why cars parked outside overnight are often covered with condensation, Gan saysโtheir metal roofs dissipate heat into the sky, cooling the surfaces below the ambient air temperature. Thatโs how you get dew. Humans have harnessed this basic natural process for thousands of years. Desert peoples in Iran, North Africa, and India manufactured ice by leaving pools of water exposed to clear desert skies overnight, when radiativโฆ

AI Wrapped: The 14 AI terms you couldnโt avoid in 2025
items.summary: If the past 12 months have taught us anything, itโs that the AI hype train is showing no signs of slowing. Itโs hard to believe that at the beginning of the year, DeepSeek had yet to turn the entire industry on its head, Meta was better known for trying (and failing) to make the metaverseโฆ
items.body: If the past 12 months have taught us anything, itโs that the AI hype train is showing no signs of slowing. Itโs hard to believe that at the beginning of the year, DeepSeek had yet to turn the entire industry on its head, Meta was better known for trying (and failing) to make the metaverse cool than for its relentless quest to dominate superintelligence, and vibe coding wasnโt a thing. If thatโs left you feeling a little confused, fear not. As we near the end of 2025, our writers have taken a look back over the AI terms that dominated the year, for better or worse. Make sure you take the time to brace yourself for what promises to be another bonkers year. โRhiannon Williams 1. Superintelligence As long as people have been  hyping  AI, they have been coming up with names for a future, ultra-powerful form of the technology that could bring about utopian or  dystopian  consequences for humanity. โSuperintelligenceโ is that latest hot term. Meta  announced  in July that it would form an AI team to pursue superintelligence, and it was reportedly offering nine-figure compensation packages to AI experts from the companyโs competitors to join. In December, Micโฆ

items.title: Meet the man hunting the spies in your smartphone
items.summary: In April 2025, Ronald Deibert left all electronic devices at home in Toronto and boarded a plane. When he landed in Illinois, he took a taxi to a mall and headed directly to the Apple Store to purchase a new laptop and iPhone. Heโd wanted to keep the risk of having his personal devices confiscatedโฆ
items.body: In April 2025, Ronald Deibert left all electronic devices at home in Toronto and boarded a plane. When he landed in Illinois, he took a taxi to a mall and headed directly to the Apple Store to purchase a new laptop and iPhone. Heโd wanted to keep the risk of having his personal devices confiscated to a minimum, because he knew his work made him a prime target for surveillance. โIโm traveling under the assumption that I am being watched, right down to exactly where I am at any moment,โ Deibert says. Deibert directs the Citizen Lab, a research center he founded in 2001 to serve as โcounterintelligence for civil society.โ Housed at the University of Toronto, the lab operates independently of governments or corporate interests, relying instead on research grants and private philanthropy for financial support. Itโs one of the few institutions that investigate cyberthreats exclusively in the public interest, and in doing so, it has exposed some of the most egregious digital abuses of the past two decades. For many years, Deibert and his colleagues have held up the US as the standard for liberal democracy. But thatโs changing, he says: โThe pillars of democracy are under assault in the Uโฆ

items.title: Four bright spots in climate news in 2025
items.summary: Climate news hasnโt been great in 2025. Global greenhouse-gas emissions hit record highs (again). This year is set to be either the second or third warmest on record. Climate-fueled disasters like wildfires in California and flooding in Indonesia and Pakistan devastated communities and caused billiโฆ
items.body: Climate news hasnโt been great in 2025. Global greenhouse-gas emissions hit record highs (again). This year is set to be either the second or third warmest on record. Climate-fueled disasters like wildfires in California and flooding in Indonesia and Pakistan devastated communities and caused billions in damage. In addition to these worrying indicators of our continued contributions to climate change and their obvious effects, the worldโs largest economy has made a sharp U-turn on climate policy this year. The US under the Trump administration withdrew from the Paris Agreement , cut funds for climate research , and scrapped billions of dollars in funding for climate tech projects. Weโre in a severe situation with climate change. But for those looking for bright spots, there was some good news in 2025. Here are a few of the positive stories our climate reporters noticed this year. Chinaโs flattening emissions GETTY IMAGES One of the most notable and encouraging signs of progress this year occurred in China. The worldโs second-biggest economy and biggest climate polluter has managed to keep carbon dioxide emissions flat for the last year and a half, according to an analysis in Carboโฆ
